1.brief: to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
happiness; only in masculine plural construction as interjection, how happy!
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a command, whether human or divine (collectively, the Law)
properly, to incline to; by implication (literally but rarely) to bend; figuratively, to be pleased with, desire
properly, vehemence, i.e. (with or without preposition) vehemently; by implication, wholly, speedily, etc. (often with other words as an intensive or superlative; especially when repeated)

2.brief: the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
seed; figuratively, fruit, plant, sowing-time, posterity
properly, a revolution of time, i.e. an age or generation; also a dwelling
to kneel; by implication to bless God (as an act of adoration), and (vice-versa) man (as a benefit); also (by euphemism) to curse (God or the king, as treason)

3.brief: a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
to stand, in various relations (literal and figurative, intransitive and transitive)
properly, a (peremptory) terminus, i.e. (by implication) duration, in the sense of advance or perpetuity (substantially as a noun, either with or without a preposition)

4.brief: properly, to irradiate (or shoot forth beams), i.e. to rise (as the sun); specifically, to appear (as a symptom of leprosy)
the dark; hence (literally) darkness; figuratively, misery, destruction, death, ignorance, sorrow, wickedness
illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)

5.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
properly, to bend or stoop in kindness to an inferior; to favor, bestow; causatively to implore (i.e. move to favor by petition)
properly, to twine, i.e. (by implication) to unite, to remain; also to borrow (as a form of obligation) or (caus.) to lend
properly, to keep in; hence, to measure; figuratively, to maintain (in various senses)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style

6.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
properly, concealed, i.e. the vanishing point; generally, time out of mind (past or future), i.e. (practically) eternity; frequentatively, adverbial (especially with prepositional prefix) always
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to waver; by implication, to slip, shake, fall
a memento, abstractly recollection (rarely if ever); by implication, commemoration
properly, concealed, i.e. the vanishing point; generally, time out of mind (past or future), i.e. (practically) eternity; frequentatively, adverbial (especially with prepositional prefix) always
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)

7.brief: bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
figuratively, to trust, be confident or sure
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

8.brief: to prop (literally or figuratively); reflexively, to lean upon or take hold of (in a favorable or unfavorable sense)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to fear; morally, to revere; caus. to frighten
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
who, which, what, that; also (as an adverb and a conjunction) when, where, how, because, in order that, etc.
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
narrow; (as a noun) a tight place (usually figuratively, i.e. trouble); also a pebble ; (transitive) an opponent (as crowding)

9.brief: to scatter, whether in enmity or bounty
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
to stand, in various relations (literal and figurative, intransitive and transitive)
properly, a (peremptory) terminus, i.e. (by implication) duration, in the sense of advance or perpetuity (substantially as a noun, either with or without a preposition)
a horn (as projecting); by implication, a flask, cornet; by resemblance. an elephant's tooth (i.e. ivory), a corner (of the altar), a peak (of a mountain), a ray (of light); figuratively, power
to be high actively, to rise or raise (in various applications, literally or figuratively)
properly, weight, but only figuratively in a good sense, splendor or copiousness

10.brief: morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
to trouble; by implication, to grieve, rage, be indignant
a tooth (as sharp); specifically  ivory; figuratively, a cliff
to liquefy; figuratively, to waste (with disease), to faint (with fatigue, fear or grief)
a longing; by implication, a delight (subjectively, satisfaction, objectively, a charm)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
properly, to wander away, i.e. lose oneself; by implication to perish (causative, destroy)
